Introduction

Pediatric hip pain is common in children and adolescents.  Although the differential diagnosis for pediatric hip pain is broad, the most common causes are characterized by mechanical, infectious, or autoimmune pathology.  Some features overlap, but each category has distinct features that help both to confirm the more likely diagnosis and to determine the next step in management.



  • Mechanical conditions:  Present with pain that can be acute or chronic and referred to the ipsilateral knee.  The pain is usually worse with activity.  Generally, no associated systemic symptoms are present, and inflammatory markers (eg, C-reactive protein, erythrocyte sedimentation rate) are normal.
  • Infectious conditions:  Present with acute, localized pain that is worse with activity and impairs ambulation.  Associated findings include fever, leukocytosis, and elevated inflammatory markers.
  • Autoimmune conditions:  Present with subtle pain that progresses gradually and is often episodic (exacerbations).  Other joints can be involved, and patients may develop joint stiffness that is worse with rest, although ambulation is generally preserved.  Other organ systems can be involved, including the skin (rash, nail changes), eyes (uveitis), and kidneys.  Laboratory findings include elevated inflammatory markers.


In addition, malignancy (eg, osteoid osteoma) is a less common cause of pediatric hip pain, generally presenting as chronic pain that worsens at night and is sometimes  associated with systemic symptoms (eg, fever, fatigue).  Finally, trauma can present with acute pediatric hip pain, often with overlying skin changes (eg, bruising, swelling) and other associated injuries, depending on the mechanism of injury.

Clinical presentation and diagnosis



Clinical presentation varies, depending on the underlying condition.  In most cases, evaluation begins with a thorough history to better characterize the pain (eg, onset, location, duration), which is the first step in determining the cause.  Acute pain, for example, is more consistent with infection or trauma, whereas chronic pain suggests an autoimmune or mechanical etiology.  In addition to the history, objective physical examination, laboratory results, and radiographic findings help determine the diagnosis.

Physical examination



  • Gait:  Inability to bear weight is concerning for serious pathology.
  • Positioning:  A hip kept in flexion, abduction, and external rotation suggests increased intraarticular pressure, usually from joint effusion.
  • Range of motion:  Pain or resistance to internal rotation further suggests intraarticular involvement.
  • Overlying skin changes:  Erythema and warmth point toward inflammation or infection.

Laboratory and imaging studies



  • Complete blood count:  Can show leukocytosis in infectious and autoimmune conditions; cytopenias suggest bone marrow suppression, possibly due to malignancy.
  • Inflammatory markers:  Elevated in infectious and autoimmune conditions.
  • Lactate dehydrogenase:  Elevated in malignancy due to increased cell turnover.
  • Targeted testing:  May be warranted depending on clinical findings (eg, arthrocentesis for suspected septic arthritis).
  • Radiographs:  Used to evaluate skeletal abnormalities such as fractures and tumors.
  • Ultrasonography:  Can evaluate for joint effusion.
  • MRI:  Provides the highest-resolution image for intraarticular and soft tissue causes.


These laboratory and imaging studies can identify conditions requiring immediate intervention (eg, septic arthritis) while also guiding management of less urgent conditions.

Common etiologies of pediatric hip pain

Mechanical: Legg-CalvÃ©-Perthes disease



  • Pathogenesis (

    ):  Legg-CalvÃ©-Perthes (LCP) disease involves idiopathic avascular necrosis of the femoral head, likely due to recurrent ischemia of the femoral head.  LCP disease classically occurs in boys age 3-12, with a peak incidence at age 6.
  • Clinical presentation:  Involves insidious, unilateral hip pain that can be referred to the thigh or knee and an antalgic gait.  In severe cases, hip abduction and internal rotation are restricted, and proximal thigh atrophy and Trendelenburg sign (pelvis drops on contralateral side with ambulation) are present (
    figure 1
    ).
  • Diagnosis:  Requires a high index of suspicion because initial radiographs are typically normal but may show joint space widening with subchondral lucency of the femoral head.  In these cases of LCP disease, persistent symptoms prompt repeat imaging, which shows femoral head sclerosis, fragmentation, and flattening (
    image 1
    ).
  • Management:  Involves avoidance of weight-bearing activities, as well as splinting or surgery to maintain the femoral head within the acetabulum.
  • Prognosis:  Depends on age and degree of femoral head involvement at the time of diagnosis, with an increased risk of degenerative arthritis in those with advanced age and/or femoral head involvement.

Mechanical: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis



  • Pathogenesis (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
    ):  Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) occurs when excess shearing forces weaken the proximal femoral physis (ie, growth plate), displacing the proximal femoral diaphysis anterosuperiorly (
    figure 2
    ).  Obese adolescents are at highest risk due to increased mechanical strain on the hip.
  • Clinical presentation:  Involves insidious, unilateral hip pain that can be referred to the thigh or knee, restricted internal rotation, and an antalgic gait.  Thigh or knee pain alone is reported in approximately 15% of SCFE cases, leading to delayed diagnosis and complications.  At rest, the affected lower extremity remains externally rotated for comfort.
  • Diagnosis:  Radiographs show posterior and inferior displacement of the femoral head along the plane of the physis, giving the appearance of "ice cream slipping off a cone" (
    image 2
    ).  Bilateral involvement is common, and imaging of both hips should be obtained.


  • Management:  Involves avoidance of weight-bearing activities to prevent further displacement and immediate surgical pinning of the physis.
  • Prognosis:  Delayed surgical pinning can result in avascular necrosis and increased risk of degenerative arthritis.

Infectious: Septic arthritis



  • Pathogenesis (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
    ):  Septic arthritis involves bacterial infection of the joint space and results in rapid joint destruction.  Staphylococcus aureus, group B Streptococcus, and gram-negative bacilli are the most common pathogens in patients age <3 months.  Staphylococcus aureus and group A Streptococcus are the most common pathogens in patients age â‰¥3 months.  In most cases, septic arthritis follows an upper respiratory or skin infection in which transient bacteremia allows hematogenous spread to the joint space.
  • Clinical presentation:  Involves acute, unilateral hip pain.  Patients keep the affected hip flexed, abducted, and externally rotated and refuse to bear weight due to the severity of the pain (
    figure 3
    ).  Patients are generally ill-appearing with fever â‰¥38.5 C (101.3 F).
  • Diagnosis:  Laboratory studies show an elevated white blood cell count and inflammatory markers.  Arthrocentesis shows grossly purulent synovial fluid with a leukocyte count >50,000/mm3.  Given the likelihood of hematogeneous spread, blood and synovial fluid cultures should be obtained to identify the causative organism.
  • Management:  Involves immediate surgical drainage and debridement.  Intravenous antibiotics should be administered immediately after blood and synovial fluid specimens have been obtained for culture.
  • Prognosis:  Favorable with prompt diagnosis and management.  Delays in surgical drainage and antibiotic administration can result in permanent joint damage, including avascular necrosis of the femoral head.

Autoimmune: Transient synovitis



  • Pathogenesis (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
    ):  Although the exact pathogenesis is unknown, transient synovitis is characterized by transient inflammation of the synovium, usually following an acute viral respiratory or gastrointestinal infection.
  • Clinical presentation:  Involves acute, unilateral hip pain that causes an antalgic gait (limp) and limited range of motion on the affected side.  Patients are generally well-appearing and afebrile.
  • Diagnosis:  Transient synovitis is a diagnosis of exclusion.  Laboratory studies are generally normal.  Ultrasonography often shows a small effusion (either unilateral or bilateral).
  • Management:  Supportive, with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents as needed for pain.
  • Prognosis:  Most patients fully recover within 1-2 weeks, although recurrence is common.

Autoimmune: Rheumatologic conditions



  • Pathogenesis (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 5
    ):  Rheumatologic conditions are autoimmune diseases that cause joint inflammation and pain.  Certain types of juvenile idiopathic arthritis can present with isolated hip pain, especially in adolescent girls.  Other rheumatologic conditions (eg, systemic lupus erythematosus, acute rheumatic fever) involve multiple joints, especially the hips, and organ systems.
  • Clinical presentation:  Involves chronic joint pain, stiffness, and swelling that is worse in the morning.  Systemic symptoms, including fever, rash, and hepatosplenomegaly, may be present.
  • Diagnosis:  Involves a thorough history and physical examination.  Laboratory findings are supportive and include elevated inflammatory markers, leukocytosis, and normocytic anemia (ie, anemia of chronic disease).  Radiographs may show joint space narrowing and bony erosions.
  • Management:  The underlying diagnosis determines management, which often involves a combination of NSAIDs, disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (eg, methotrexate), and glucocorticoids.
  • Prognosis:  Most rheumatologic conditions are chronic and require lifelong therapy to minimize the risk of complications.

Summary



Hip pain is common in children and adolescents and requires careful evaluation.  The differential diagnosis for pediatric hip pain is broad and includes mechanical (eg, Legg-CalvÃ©-Perthes disease, slipped capital femoral epiphysis), infectious (eg, septic arthritis), and autoimmune (eg, transient synovitis, rheumatologic conditions) etiologies.
